Colours

Eezo comes with the ability to change colours of some properties such as text, background-color and borders. The colours can also be customised in sass by changing the default values or adding more colours.

Default Colours

These are the default colours that come with Eezo, they are mostly just nice defaults for general UI purposes with a slightly cool hue for greys.

The black and white colors are both set to a "nicer" shade with no saturation. And the greys are slightly saturated with a cool hue. why? read this.

class name hex value example
x transparent
wht #ffffff
white #f9f9f9
cream #f7f2eb
light #b5b8bf
grey #82848e
dark #575c67
pitch #161f23
black #1a1a1a
blk #000000

Extra Colours

The extra colours are just some "pretty OK" colours to jump-start your ui. They only come with the Core+ bundle and can be easily overridden with customisation in sass.

class name hex value example
silver #dde3e6
gold #c7aa5c
yellow #d6d01e
orange #d66a1e
red #d61e40
pink #ec2666
violet #981bd8
purple #5930d6
blue #1e9bd6
teal #17b5b5
mint #31e894
green #1ed668

Customising

There's a global set map set to the $colors variable which is inherited by all othe colour modules (text, background, etc).

The $colors map is a combination of:

  • $base-colors ( as shown above under "default colours" )
  • $extra-colors ( a map of some nice ui colours )
  • $custom-colors ( an empty map which can be supplied )

Base Colours

These cannot be overridden, they are pretty standard across most UIs.

Extra Colours

Extra Colours may be turned on, or off, by changing the boolean variable, $no-extra-colors, to true. (default is false).

// switch off the extra colours by 
// placing this code _before_ your eezo 
// import/include. e.g:
$no-extra-colors: true;

Custom Colours

If you'd prefer to supply your own set of colours to persist across the framework, you may do so by supplying them in a map called $custom-colors.

Any colours supplied in $custom-colors, that share the same name as a colour in the default/extras map, will override the default version.

// Customise the colours for eezo,
// - add some of our own colours
// - override the default black colour.
// - override the extra red colour.
$custom-colors: (
    facebook-blue:  #3b5998,
    twitter-blue:   #55acee,
    black:          #010101,
    red:            #cc0000,
);

We would now be able to reference the facebook/twitter colours, as well as our custom black/red anywhere that inherits them;

<body class="txt-black">
    <!-- Body has our custom black text colour -->
    <h3 class="bor-1 bor-red"> Share </h3>
    <!-- Heading has our custom red as border -->
    <a href="facebook.com" class="bg-facebook-blue"> Facebook </a>
    <a href="twitter.com" class="bg-twitter-blue"> Twitter </a>
    <!-- Links have custom background colours -->
</body>

More information

See the following sections regarding the different properties that inherit colours:

  • Text colours
  • Background colours
  • Border colours
  • SVG fills

view the source on github: /src/defaults/_colors.scss
